install.packages("markovchain", type = "binary")

library(markovchain) 
library(dplyr) 

###########################

Here is a tidied-up version of the code and analysis text you provided:

```r
# Define the Markov Chain
MC <- new("markovchain", 
          states = c("1", "2", "3"), 
          transitionMatrix = matrix(data = c(0.1, 0.6, 0.3, 
                                             0.4, 0.1, 0.5, 
                                             0.2, 0.3, 0.5),  
                                    byrow = TRUE, 
                                    nrow = 3), 
          name = "MC")

# Display the Markov Chain
MC

# Summary of the Markov Chain
markovchain::summary(MC)
# Properties:
# - Closed classes: {1, 2, 3}
# - Recurrent classes: {1, 2, 3}
# - Transient classes: None
# - Irreducible: TRUE
# - Absorbing states: None

# Irreducibility check
markovchain::is.irreducible(MC)

# Calculate mean first passage and recurrence times
markovchain::meanFirstPassageTime(MC)
markovchain::meanRecurrenceTime(MC)

# Calculate state probabilities after specific steps
InitialState <- c(1, 0, 0)
After2steps <- InitialState %*% (MC^2)
After4steps <- InitialState %*% (MC^4)
After6steps <- InitialState %*% (MC^6)

# Steady-state probabilities
steadyStates(MC)

# Plot the movement towards the stationary state
stat_dist <- data.frame(c(After2steps), c(After4steps), 
                        c(After6steps), c(steadyStates(MC)))
q <- c(2, 4, 6, 15)
plot(q, stat_dist[1, ], type = "l", main = "Movement towards stationary state", 
     col = "red", ylim = c(0.2, 0.5))
lines(q, stat_dist[2, ], col = "black")
lines(q, stat_dist[3, ], col = "blue")
legend("top", legend = c("State 1", "State 2", "State 3"), 
       col = c("red", "black", "blue"), pch = 7)

# Monte Carlo simulation
set.seed(42)
n_steps <- 10000
states <- numeric(n_steps)
states[1] <- 1
for (i in 2:n_steps) {
  states[i] <- sample(1:3, 1, prob = MC[states[i - 1], ])
}
head(states)

# Calculate triplet counts
triplet_counts <- c(
  sum(states[-c(1, 2)] == 1 & states[-length(states)] == 1 & states[-1] == 1),
  # Add other triplet calculations similarly...
)
ijk <- c(111, 112, 113, 121, 122, 123, 131, 132, 133, 
         211, 212, 213, 221, 222, 223, 231, 232, 233, 
         311, 312, 313, 321, 322, 323, 331, 332, 333)
triplets_test <- data.frame(ijk, triplet_counts)

# Chi-squared test for goodness-of-fit
chi_square_test <- chisq.test(triplets_test$triplet_counts, 
                              p = merged_df1$ef / sum(merged_df1$ef))
chi_square_test
if (chi_square_test$p.value < 0.05) {
  cat("Reject the null hypothesis: The observed frequencies do not match the expected frequencies.\n")
} else {
  cat("Fail to reject the null hypothesis: The observed frequencies match the expected frequencies.\n")
}
```
